w:r.w:t: In FP progams are built from expressions:
Method naming - note that x+y is equivalent (and rewritten by the compiler) to x.+(y):
- passing a child where a parent would be expected
A type parameter A of a generic class can be made covariant by using the annotation +A.
For some class List[+A], making A covariant implies that for two types A and B where A is a
of B, then List[A] is a subtype of List[B]
case class Cat(name: String) extends Animal
case class Dog(name: String) extends Animal
Both Cat and Dog are subtypes of Animal.
Scala standard library has a generic immutable sealed abstract class List[

the type parameter A is covariant. This means that a List[Cat] is a List[Animal] and a List[Dog] is also a List[Animal]. Intuitively, it makes sense that a list of cats and a list of dogs are each lists of animals, and you should be able to substitute either of them for a List[Animal].

In the following example, the method printAnimalNames will accept a list of animals as an argument and print their names each on a new line. If List[A] were not covariant, the last two method calls would not compile, which would severely limit the usefulness of the printAnimalNames method.
// passing child where a parent would be expected
// passing child where a parent would be expected
- means you can substitute a parent for a child
or IOW pass a parent where a child would be expected:

A type parameter A of a generic class can be made contravariant by using the annotation -A. This creates a subtyping relationship between the class and its type parameter that is similar, but opposite to what we get with covariance. That is, for some class Writer[-A], making A contravariant implies that for two types A and B where A is a subtype of B, Writer[B] is a subtype of Writer[A].
Consider the Cat, Dog, and Animal classes defined above for the following example:
case class Cat(name: String) extends Animal
case class Dog(name: String) extends Animal
//passing a parent where a child would be expected
Generic classes in Scala are invariant by default
. This means that they are neither covariant nor contravariant. In the context of the following example, Container class is invariant.
A Container[Cat] is not a Container[Animal], nor is the reverse true.
case class Cat(name: String) extends Animal
case class Dog(name: String) extends Animal
//if above assignment of catContainer to animalContainer were allowed then this would cause a problem:
val cat: Cat = catContainer.getValue // Oops, we'd end up with a Dog assigned to a Cat

It may seem like a Container[Cat] should naturally also be a Container[Animal], but allowing a mutable generic class to be covariant would not be safe. In this example, it is very important that Container is invariant.
Case classes are good for modeling immutable data
They are also useful in pattern matching
subclasses of a sealed class (abstract or not) must be in the same file. A practical consequence of this is that the compiler can warn if the pattern match is incomplete:
case class Node(left: Tree, right: Tree) extends Tree
se class Leaf[T](value: T) extends Tree
def dps(t: Tree): Unit = t match {
